Ga-doped spinel-typed Co-Al catalysts for CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation Shuyang Xu Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Weiming Hua Methodology Conceptualization Yinghong Yue Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Zi Gao Supervision Department of Chemistry, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, PR China Department of Chemistry, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Fudan University Shanghai 200438 PR China Department of Chemistry, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Fudan University, Shanghai 200438, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. A series of Ga-doped spinel-typed Co-Al catalysts were prepared via one-step evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method. These catalysts present promising catalytic performance for CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation, which can be ascribed to the conjunction effect of cobalt and gallium species. The incorporation of Ga into the structure of Co-Al spinel has been recognized for enhancing CO2 conversion via reverse water-gas shift reaction, leading to a favorable equilibrium shift towards ethylene, along with an improved catalyst stability as a result of coexisting Boudouard reaction. Through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), NH3 and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) characterizations, coordinatively unsaturated Co2+ and Ga3+ cations were identified as collaborative catalytic active sites, with gallium species taking the prominent role. These sites were closely associated with the formation of acid-base pairs on the catalyst surface, which were crucial for the adsorption and activation of the reactants. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ethane dehydrogenation CoAl2O4 spinel Gallium oxide Carbon dioxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As one of the simplest olefins, ethylene holds paramount importance in the realm of petrochemical industry for its indispensable role in the production of various polymers and chemicals such as polyethylene, polyvinyl chloride, polystyrene, ethylene glycol, and ethylene oxide [1,2]. In recent years, propelled by the technological innovation, there has been a thriving emergence of new material applications using ethylene and its derivatives as the feedstock, driving further extension of the industry chain and resulting in a steady growth in global ethylene demand [3–5]. Due to the shale gas revolution and the prevalence of liquefied natural gas (LNG) technologies, ethane dehydrogenation (EDH), a process that converts ethane into ethylene and hydrogen, has emerged as a viable choice to produce ethylene, an alternative to the conventional one through steam cracking of petroleum hydrocarbons, which is always criticized as energy-intensive and high-polluting [6,7]. The CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene is a more promising way, since the limited thermodynamic equilibrium can be promoted via reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction [8]. Pt- and Cr- based catalysts have exhibited excellent dehydrogenation activity and alkene selectivity in light alkane dehydrogenation [9,10]. However, there exists the non-negligible problem because of the limited availability or toxicity. As a result, other metal elements which are relatively more affordable and environmentally friendly, such as Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Ga, Mo, V, etc., have currently become a hotspot for investigation [2]. Till now, a wide variety of Co-based catalysts, have been proven to be effective in alkane dehydrogenation process, including cobalt-molecular sieve catalysts such as Co-silicalite-1 [11–13], Co/HMS [14], Co/ZSM-5 [15], Co/MOR [16], Co@MCM-41 [17], and cobalt-oxide catalysts like Co/SiO2 [18], Co/Al2O3 [19–22], Co/ZrO2 [23], CoO-MoOx [24], Co/TiO2 [25], ZnCo/NC [26], Co-Zr/SiO2 [27]. Abundant exploration concerning the active sites has also been carried out and the prevailing viewpoint suggests that isolated Co(II) possesses remarkable ability in C-H bonds activation, facilitating the dehydrogenation. Taking Co/Al2O3 for example, the tetrahedral Co2+ ions in “surface spinel” structure is proposed to constituted the active sites for propane dehydrogenation (PDH), while Co0 species produced by the reduction of crystalline Co3O4 led to reforming and cracking pathways [28]. The PDH activity of tetrahedral Co2+ sites within the Co-Al spinel were later proved by a direct investigation of the cobalt aluminate spinel catalyst prepared by a one-step method [29]. Recent research has further proved that coordinatively unsaturated Co-O acid-base pairs via lattice oxygen consumption are the PDH active sites of CoOx/Al2O3 catalysts through the combination of in situ/operando Raman spectroscopy and in situ UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy together with density functional theory calculations [30]. The active Co2+ ions could also be anchored by pentacoordinate Al3+ in Al2O3 nanorod to form CoAl2O4 spinel phase, which inhibited the formation of Co3O4 particles and their reduction to Co0 during the reaction, thus improved the propylene selectivity [20]. Ethane can also be converted into ethylene over Co-BaCO3 through an oxidative dehydrogenation process where CO2 acted as a mild oxidant in the redox cycle between Co4+-O and Co n+-O (n＜4) [31]. Koirala et al. investigated a series of Co-loaded catalysts produced by ﬂame spray pyrolysis and revealed that CO2 cast a promotion effect to dehydrogenation over these catalysts by consuming H2 through RWGS reaction which shifts the equilibrium to ethylene [32,33]. It is also believed that CO2 can improve the catalyst stability by eliminating coke deposition through the reverse Boudouard reaction [33]. However, the reported Co-based catalysts for CO2-assisted dehydrogenation are still far from satisfactory, particularly in terms of CO2 activation. Besides, dry reforming of ethane often takes place simultaneously in addition to dehydrogenation over Co-based catalysts [15]. Various optimization strategies have been proposed. A recent study reported a dual-atom catalyst (DAC) featuring paired ZnCo active sites anchored on N-doped carbon for PDH, reaching both higher activity and selectivity compared with the single-atom catalyst (SAC) containing only Zn or Co [26]. The synergistic effect between Co2+ and Zr4+ was also found over Co/ZrO2 catalyst, which exhibits much higher activity in PDH than the sum of activities of Co2+ sites on SiO2 and Zr4+ sites in unpromoted ZrO2 [23]. These findings highlight the feasibility of incorporating a second metal into the catalyst for further amelioration. Ga is thought to be an ideal candidate for this strategy, since Ga2O3 was found to be effective for CO2-assisted dehydrogenation with its outstanding performance for CO2 activation among various metal oxides [34]. Multiple forms of active Ga species have been revealed, including tetrahedrally coordinated Ga3+ ions generally found in Ga-based oxides catalysts, and Ga+, [GaO]+, [Ga2O2]2+, [GaH2]+, [GaH]2+, Ga+-H+ species existing in zeolite-based catalysts [35]. Enhanced performance for CO2-assisted PDH was reported over a spinel-typed Ga2O3-Al2O3 solid solution as compared with pure Ga2O3, which was attributed to the modified surface acidity originating from the specific interaction between Ga2O3 and Al2O3 [36]. Similar results were obtained over Ga-doped MgAl2O4 spinel in CO2-assisted EDH reaction, further demonstrating that the coordinative unsaturated tetrahedral Ga3+ ions played a key role in CO2-assisted dehydrogenation [37]. Recently, Han et al. looked into one-dimensional Ga2O3-Al2O3 nanofibers and proposed that PDH had a wonderful synergy with RWGS reaction over Ga3+-O-Al3+ sites, thus promoting forward the reaction kinetics [38]. However, despite the excellent activity of Ga, it always has an optimal content within the catalysts to reach upper limited performance, ascribing to the formation of less active Ga3+-O-Ga3+ sites and/or octahedral Ga3+ ions in catalysts when Ga content exceeding the “ideal value”. Further improvements are still needed. Starting from these grounds, herein, we developed a series of Ga-doped spinel-typed Co-Al catalysts with varying Ga/Al ratio and Co content, whose catalytic behavior for ethane dehydrogenation were compared either in the presence or absence of CO2. Their physicochemical properties were characterized through XRD, N2-adsorption, XPS, XAFS, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD. The conjunction effect of cobalt and gallium were discussed in detail, which was expected to form dual active sites to facilitate the ethylene production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ga-doped spinel-typed Co-Al catalysts were prepared via one-step EISA method as reported before [29]. Briefly, stoichiometric quantities of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, gallium nitrate hydrate and aluminum isopropoxide (Al3+ + Ga3+ = 0.015 mol) were dissolved in a premixed solution containing P123 (2.0 g), ethanol (40 mL) and concentrated nitric acid (3.2 mL). After vigorous stirring for 6 h at room temperature, the resulting mixture was kept still in an oven at 60 °C until the solvent was completely removed, and then calcined in air at 700 °C for 5 h at a ramp rate of 1 °C/min. The obtained products were labeled as CoGa x Al6-x (x = 0, 2, 3, 4, 6) or Co y Ga3Al3 (y = 0, 0.5, 2). 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a D2 PHASER X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation to investigate the crystalline phases of the samples. A Micromeritics TriStar II analysor was applied to obtain N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, from which the specific surface areas were calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the pore volumes by one-point method and the pore size distributions by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed on an Agilent 5110 spectrometer. The morphology of the samples was revealed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a Phenom Prox instrument and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin instrument. XPS was detected on an AXIS Kratos Supra+ spectrometer, employing Al-Kα radiation as the excitation source. The calibration of the binding energy was conducted with reference to the C1 s peak of the contaminant carbon at 284.8 eV. The amount of coke deposition was identified using the thermogravimetry (TG) analysis carried out on TGA8000 apparatus, and calculated by the difference between the two plateau values of weight decrease during the heating process (about 300–600°C). Ga K-edge analysis was performed with Si(111) crystal monochromators at the BL11B beamlines at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) (Shanghai, China). The XAFS spectra were recorded at room temperature using a 4-channel Silicon Drift Detector (SDD) Bruker 5040 and the Ga K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were recorded in transmission mode. The spectra were processed and analyzed by the software codes Athena and Artemis. The surface acidity and basicity of the samples were measured by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD respectively, operated on an Auto Chem II instrument (Micromeritics, Atlanta, GA, USA). Approximately 0.1 g sample was pretreated in nitrogen flow at 650 °C for 1 h before adsorption. After the temperature was reduced to 100 °C, the flow was switched to 10 vol% NH3/He or 5 vol% CO2/He (30 mL/min) and kept for 2 h, followed by purging with pure helium (30 mL/min) for another 2 h. The desorption rate was subsequently monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min up to 700 °C. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) were performed using the same apparatus as TPD test. 0.1 g sample was loaded on a quartz tube and purged with helium at 300 °C for 2 h with the flow rate of 30 mL/min. After cooling down to RT, TPR test was conducted after switching the flow of 10 vol% H2/Ar. The signal from TCD was recorded in the range of 100–800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalytic testing The reaction was conducted in a fixed-bed flow microreactor under atmospheric pressure. A catalyst mass of 0.2 g sieved by 40∼60 mesh was loaded in the middle of a quartz tube (inner diameter of 6 mm and length of 45 cm). Before the reaction, the catalyst was pretreated in a N2 atmosphere for 1 h at 650 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Then, 3 vol% ethane and the balance N2 were introduced at a total flow rate of 30 mL/min during the direct dehydrogenation. For CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation, the reactant was consisted of 3 vol% ethane, 6 vol% CO2 and the balance N2. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) is 9000 mL/(gcat·h). An online gas chromatography (GC) was applied for product analysis, which has a flame ionization detector (FID) with a 6 m packed column of Porapak Q for hydrocarbon detection (e.g. C2H6, C2H4, CH4) and a TCD with a 2 m packed column of TDX-01 for other gas detection (e.g. H2, N2, CO, CO2). Ethane conversion χ(C2H6), ethylene selectivity S(C2H4), methane selectivity S(CH4) and ethylene yield Y(C2H4) were determined using the following formula, in which C 2 H 6 in represents the amount of C2H6 fed in the reactant, while C 2 H 6 out , C 2 H 4 out and C H 4 out refer to the amount of C2H6, C2H4 and CH4 in the tail gas: χ C 2 H 6 = C 2 H 6 in − C 2 H 6 out C 2 H 6 in × 100 % S ( C 2 H 4 ) = C 2 H 4 out C 2 H 6 in − C 2 H 6 out × 100 % S ( C H 4 ) = C H 4 out C 2 H 6 in − C 2 H 6 out × 100 % Y ( C 2 H 4 ) = χ ( C 2 H 6 ) × S ( C 2 H 4 ) S ( Others ) = 1 − S ( C 2 H 4 ) − S ( C H 4 ) RWGS reaction was conducted in the same microreactor, following a similar process as described above except that H2/CO2/N2 = 1:1:1 with a total flow rate of 30 mL/min was fed as reagent gas. All test results could be reproducible within the precision of 5 %. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterization Fig. 1 depicts the XRD patterns of the prepared CoGa x Al6-x catalysts. CoAl6 sample exhibits characteristic diffraction peaks consistent with the spinel-structured CoAl2O4 (PDF#44–0160). A distinct peak-shift towards lower angles can be seen as the Ga/Al ratio increases, which was caused by the gradual replacement of lattice Al atom by Ga atom and the formation of a relatively uniform spinel-structured solid solution. Spinel structure of CoGa2O4 (PDF#11–0698) can be observed on CoGa6 sample. And notably, there is an extra peak at about 31.8°, indicating the existence of Ga2O3 phase (Figure S1) due to the excessive feeding of gallium precursor beyond the stoichiometric ratio of the spinel. No peaks corresponding to the CoOx phase were detected, indicating a good lattice dispersion of Co species within all these samples. The morphologies of catalysts were revealed using SEM and TEM techniques. All catalysts exhibit irregular, fragmentary morphologies with varying particle sizes and rough surfaces, as shown in Figure S2. Elemental mapping of CoGa3Al3 (Figure S3), taken as an example, shows that all contained elements (Co, Ga, Al, and O) were well dispersed. Fig. 2 shows the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of CoGa3Al3 and CoGa6 catalysts, from which the lattice fringes of spinel could be noticed. Meanwhile, the presence of crystallized gallium oxide on CoGa6 was confirmed, corresponding with the XRD results. The textural properties of these CoGa x Al6-x catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption. All samples exhibit type IV adsorption isotherms as depicted in Figure S4, indicating the presence of mesoporous or macroporous structure due to the accumulation of grains. The detailed results are listed in Table 1. Sample CoAl6 possesses the highest abundance of mesopores as well as the largest specific surface area of 177 m2/g. With the increase of gallium doping, both of the specific surface area and the pore volume diminishes accordingly, which may pose an adverse effect on the dispersion of active species and the number of exposed active sites on surface. Therefore, it is reasonable that the maximum activity over these catalysts should be reached with proper Ga-doping. 3.2 State of Co and Ga species In order to investigate the chemical state of Co species within the catalysts, UV–vis analysis was conducted. As shown in Fig. 3, all the catalysts exhibit triple absorption bands located at around 550, 590 and 630 nm, assigned to the 4A2(F) → 4T1(P) d-d transition of tetrahedral Co(II). The weak peak at around 480 nm can be ascribed to the spin-forbidden d-d transition of these Co species. No peaks related to other forms of Co species was detected, indicating that the vast majority of Co species exist in the form of tetrahedrally coordinated Co(II) within a homogeneous solid solution, instead of CoOx clusters or particles. Furthermore, a systematic red-shift in the wavelength of the characteristic triplet can be observed with the increasing Ga/Al ratio, which was probably due to the different coordination and electronic environment for Co(II) species caused by the introduction of Ga atom into the lattice. As for Ga species, the Ga K-edge XANES derived from the 1 s → 4p electronic transitions of Ga atoms was applied to provide further insights into their local structure, as depicted in Fig. 4A. β-Ga2O3 is used as a reference due to its known spinel structure with Ga atoms evenly distributed across tetrahedral (Td) and octahedral (Oh) sites in the lattice. Typically, the white-line peaks at around 10,375 eV and 10,378 eV correspond to Ga atoms in Ga-O4 tetrahedra and Ga-O6 octahedra, respectively. As a result, the presence of a broad peak ranging from 10,370 eV to 10,380 eV preliminarily suggests the coexistence of Ga species in both sites. While the variation in edge-intensity of these peaks could be ascribed to the diverse site occupancy of lattice Ga atoms. To further analyze the quantitative Ga occupancy in each sample, Athena and FEFF calculations were applied to deconvolute the white-line peaks of Ga K-edge XANES spectrum, as reported before [39]. The curve-fitting was carried out on the assumption that the main peak (10,365 eV to 10,385 eV) was composed of two parts, each consisted an arctangent curve for continuum absorption and a pseudo-Voigt curve for the white-line. The fitting procedures and results are provided in Figure S5, Table S1 and Table 2, and the fractional percentages of Ga(Td) and Ga(Oh) are calculated by using the area of fitting peaks. It is noteworthy the β-Ga2O3 reference exhibits 49.4 % of Ga (Td) and 50.6 % of Ga (Oh) atoms, aligning closely with theoretical expectations, which provides evidence for the reasonability of the above fitting method. As for CoGa x Al6-x catalysts, the fractional percentage of Ga (Td) endures a gradual decrease from 53.5 % to 44.2 % as Ga/(Al+Ga) ratio increases from 0.33 to 1, while Ga (Oh) fraction raises from 46.5 % to 55.8 %, accordingly. This trend is in great agreement with previous reports on gallium-containing spinel that lower Ga content could lead to its preference for tetrahedral-site occupation, which is considered to be crucial for the dehydrogenation [37]. The k3-weighted Ga K-edge EXAFS spectra for the catalysts were measured (Figure S6), and the Fourier transform was performed on each EXAFS spectrum in the 2–12 Å region, resulting in the radial structure function (RSF) displayed in Fig. 4B. All RSFs of Ga-containing samples are similar to that of β-Ga2O3. The peak at R = 1–2 Å can be ascribed to the back scattering of the O atoms adjacent to Ga ions, whereas the other peak at R = 2–3 Å indicates the presence of a second adjacent metal atom (Ga, Al or Co). Notably, there is a slight increase on the average Ga-O bond distances with the growing amount of Ga doping, consistent with the change in site preference of Ga ions form tetrahedral to octahedral coordination. Previous studies have also highlighted the significant influence of the concentration and chemical state of surface atoms to the catalytic performance [28,37]. Therefore, XPS was applied to give further insight into surface Ga and Co species, which are presumed to be the active components of these CoGa x Al6-x catalysts. In the Ga 2p spectra of all Ga-containing samples ( Fig. 5A), there are two bimodal peaks presented at about 1118 eV and 1145 eV, which can be attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbitals of Ga3+, respectively. These peaks are perfectly symmetrical, indicating that all gallium is trivalent without any reduced Gaδ+ (δ < 2) species. While for the spectra of Co (Fig. 5B), all samples exhibit two main peaks at around 780 eV and 796 eV, accompanied by satellite peaks with higher binding energies of 787 eV and 803 eV, corresponding to the spin orbitals of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2. The peak of Co 2p3/2 can be further deconvoluted into two parts by fitting method, attributing to Co3+ (780.9 eV) and Co2+ (782.6 eV), respectively [16]. The two satellite which is about 6 eV above the main peak should be ascribed to Co2+ ions, consistent with the previous study [40]. Notably, all Co 2p spectra exhibit almost identical peak pattern and intensity due to their similar Co content and valence state. The surface atom content has been calculated and listed in Table 2. Compared with the bulk atom ratio as determined by ICP test, a certain difference could be noticed, which shows Ga species tended to accumulate on the surface, while the exposure of Co sites was relatively limited. 3.3 Acid-base properties The surface acidity of CoGa x Al6-x catalysts was examined by the NH3-TPD method. As presented in Fig. 6A, an asymmetric broad peak in the range of 80–500°C can be observed in all curves, indicating the presence of both weak (80–200°C) and medium-strong acid sites (200–500°C) on the surface. The acidity is considered to be Lewis acidity, arising from tetracoordinated Al3+, Ga3+ or Co2+ species with unsaturated coordination because of the lack of electrons, which is proved to be essential for ethane activation through dissociative adsorption. The amount of the two types of acid sites as well as their density was further quantified, and the results are listed in Table 3. It is quite clear that the total amount of acid sites as well as the medium-strong ones decreased with the rise of Ga/Al ratio. However, the density of medium-strong acid sites showed non-monotonic trend, a tendency to increase first and then decrease with CoGa3Al3 catalyst reaching the highest value of 1.85 μmol/m2. The surface base property of the catalysts was also characterized by means of CO2-TPD. As is shown in Fig. 6B, two distinct desorption peaks around 150 ºC and 300 ºC can be observed in the TPD profile of CoAl6 and CoGa2Al4, corresponding to the weak and medium-strong basic sites, respectively. Unlike the above two catalysts, only one broad asymmetric CO2 desorption peak, ranging from 150 ºC to 350 ºC, appears for those with higher Ga content (i.e. CoGa3Al3, CoGa4Al2 and CoGa6). The total basicity of the catalysts exhibits an initial rise followed by a decline with increasing Ga content. Among all samples, CoGa3Al3 has the most abundant basic sites of 102 μmol/g, while in terms of base density, CoGa3Al3 and CoGa4Al2 were the highest. Additionally, there is an obvious decrease on the peak temperature of medium-strong basic sites with the increase of Ga-doping, implying a weakening of surface basicity upon the Ga-doping accordingly. 3.4 Catalytic activity The catalytic performances over CoGa x Al6-x catalysts in the atmosphere of N2 were investigated at 650 °C, and the detailed results are illustrated in Fig. 7 and Table 4. Methane was the only by-product detected. A certain catalytic activity could be witnessed of all the spinel catalysts, with initial ethane conversion surpassing 20 %. The introduction of a small amount of Ga species caused a significant activity enhancement, manifested in the initial ethane conversion of 40.6 % on CoGa2Al4 catalyst, much higher than that of the gallium-free CoAl6 (24.0 %) despite its possession of largest medium-strong acid sites. This is consistent with previous report that Al sites in spinel have inferior activity for dehydrogenation. Therefore, it can be preliminarily deduced that the Co and Ga species are the main catalytic active sites for ethane conversion. Replacing Al with Ga increases the number of active sites, leading to this enhancement in activity. However, with further increase of Ga/Al ratio, the catalytic activity was unchanged at first and then decreased. This could be ascribed to the change of chemical state of active species. Ga species in spinel are in the position of the tetrahedral site Ga (Td) and the octahedral site Ga (Oh), the former is usually considered as active site for dehydrogenation. As indicated in XANES, the fractional percentage of Ga (Td) decreases as the increase of Ga/Al ratio. Furthermore, Al3+-O-Ga3+ is gradually replaced by Ga3+-O-Ga3+ site with the increasing Ga incorporation. Recent reports have uncovered a synergistic effect between Ga and Al ions in alkane dehydrogenation through both experiments and DFT calculation [38,41], which is also applicable in the present case. Specifically, Al3+-O-Ga3+ is considered as the most active sites for alkane dehydrogenation, functioning through a procedure that Al3+, in conjunction with its adjacent O atom with Lewis basicity, activates the first C-H heterolysis by proton abstraction, while Ga3+ facilitates the following β-H elimination. Whereas Ga3+-O-Ga3+ sites were found to be easily blocked by dissociative adsorption of produced H2. Meanwhile, the selectivity of ethylene dropped noticeably after the introduction of Ga, implying that these catalytic sites are also very active for ethane cracking in the absence of CO2, resulting in a large amount of methane and coke deposit (manifested by selectivity of Others). When the reactivity of CoGa x Al6-x catalysts is correlated with their acidity measurements, it can be concluded that the medium-strong acid site density probably plays a crucial role in the competition between these spinel-typed catalysts. CoGa2Al4 and CoGa3Al3 are the most active catalysts because of their highest surface acid site density with medium strong strength (see Table 3), while the activities of CoAl6 and CoGa6 are lowest due to their minimum acid site density. In terms of stability, it is clear that all Ga-containing samples showed rapid deactivation during the initial period probably because of the severe coke deposition, as indicated by the high selectivity for Others (35.3–50.4 %) at 10 min. This can also be proved by their high coke amount on the catalyst surface (Table 4), which shows a close relationship with the total acidity of the catalysts. More specifically, the deactivation rate during the initial 6 h was 62.1 % for CoGa2Al4, and exceeded 80 % for CoGa3Al3, CoGa4Al2 and CoGa6, implying that more Ga doped, lower stability exhibited. CoAl6 without Ga species exhibited relatively better stability, with a deactivation rate of only 22.9 % within the same time frame, and its selectivity towards ethylene remained above 70 % throughout. CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of ethane was performed over these CoGa x Al6-x catalysts with a controlled amount of CO2 added into the feedstock, and the results are spotted in Fig. 8 and Table 5. The introduction of CO2 posed a positive impact on the dehydrogenation performance of all Ga-containing catalysts, particularly CoGa3Al3 catalyst, which exhibited the highest initial ethylene yield of 40.6 %, 23.5 % higher than that in absence of CO2. The reason of such amelioration is believed to be the coupling effect of RWGS reaction with dehydrogenation, as high CO2 conversion was achieved and CO was detected in the reaction product. And this can also be proved by their high RWGS activity at the reaction temperature (650 °C) displayed in Figure S7 and Table 5. While for CoAl6 catalyst, the dehydrogenation activity was somewhat inhibited after the addition of CO2 despite it is quite active for RWGS reaction. This is probably resulted from its stronger basic strength, which may bring about a more intense competitive adsorption of CO2 to ethane molecule on the catalyst surface. From the perspective of ethylene selectivity, all catalysts exhibited uplift results, 25∼50 % higher than that under N2 atmosphere despite of their enhanced ethane conversion. The cleavage side reaction is greatly reduced in the presence of CO2, since the selectivity of by-products, including methane and others, is notably lower. And the catalyst deactivation was effectively alleviated with the involvement of CO2. Such enhancement of catalyst stability could be attributed to the promotion of desorption of ethylene from the catalyst surface by CO2, preventing further cracking and coke formation, as reported before [42]. All can be confirmed by the results of TG analysis listed in Table 5, showing that coke deposition on CoGa3Al3 and CoGa4Al2 surface were 0.9 and 0.6, respectively, much lower than those in absence of CO2 (3.2 and 1.6). Furthermore, in order to verify the reasons for catalyst deactivation, XPS was applied again over the spent catalysts (Figure S9). The obtained spectra of Co 2p and Ga 2p shows little difference as compared with those of the fresh catalysts, indicating that the chemical states of active species are almost identical during the reaction. Regeneration experiments were then conducted over the most active catalyst CoGa3Al3 after 6 h reaction both with and without CO2, by purging with N2 for 1 h, re-calcination at 650 °C under the flowing air for 1 h followed by purging with N2 for another 1 h. As illustrated in Fig. 9, the investigated catalyst shows almost completely restored initial activity either in the presence or the absence of CO2, demonstrating that the coke deposition on the surface may take primary responsibility for the decrease in activity. A comparison of the catalytic performance of the present catalyst with those of previously investigated Co-based ones in CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of ethane was presented in Table S2. 3.5 Role of Co In the aforementioned case, the doping gallium was considered as main active sites, playing a crucial role in ethane conversion either in the absence or in the presence of CO2. To further elucidate the role of cobalt as collaborative active sites, a series of catalysts with an optimal Ga/Al ratio (1:1) and a variable of Co content, labeled as Co y Ga3Al3 (y = 0, 0.5, 2), were prepared. The composition of these catalysts was measured by ICP test and shown in Table S3, which is very close to their feed ratio. Evaluation of the catalytic performance of these samples was presented in Fig. 10 and Fig. 11, with detailed results listed in Table 6 & 7. An obvious enhancement of catalytic activity could be observed when moderate amount cobalt species were integrated into the catalysts. The cobalt-free sample, Co0Ga3Al3, exhibited much lower initial ethane conversion than Co0.5Ga3Al3, especially under CO2 atmosphere (29.0 % vs 43.9 %). The result supports the notion that both Co and Ga species serve as active catalytic sites for ethane dehydrogenation. This can be further proved by the lower activity of Mg0.5Co0.5Ga3Al3 (see Figure S8), as compared with CoGa3Al3 (Table 6 & 7). With the augment of Co content, CoGa3Al3 obtained the highest initial ethane conversion of 47.7 % in the presence of CO2, although the magnitude of the increase was greatly reduced. For Co2Ga3Al3, however, a significant decline of ethylene selectivity was spotted under both conditions (with or without CO2), indicating a transformation from dehydrogenation to undesirable cracking reaction (and/or further reforming with the participation of CO2), probably due to the changes in the state of Co species, as implied by later characterization. The XRD patterns of Co y Ga3Al3 samples were measured and displayed in Fig. 12. The diffraction pattern of Co0Ga3Al3 was found identical to the spinel-typed Ga2O3-Al2O3 mixed oxide [36]. With the integration of cobalt, there was an obvious improvement in crystallinity to form a spinel phase that is in great resemblance with the previously discussed catalysts. Notably, as the content of cobalt increases, all peaks showed a slight shift towards lower angles, suggesting that Co ions were more likely to interact with Ga ions to form CoGa2O4 spinel. The UV–vis and XPS characterization provided clearer validation for the differences in the cobalt state among these catalysts. As shown in Fig. 13, the absorption bands of Co0.5Ga3Al3 and CoGa3Al3 were similar to those of CoGa x Al6-x samples discussed before, which can be ascribed to tetracoordinated Co2+ ions. In contrast, Co2Ga3O3 exhibited two additional broad bands centered at approximately 410 nm and 750 nm, which were usually attributed to the ligand-to metal charge transfer of O2-→Co2+ and O2-→Co3+ in the Co3O4 phase [23]. Consistently, the peak fitting results of XPS ( Fig. 14B) revealed a significant increase in the proportion of Co3+ ions in Co2Ga3Al3, compared to Co0.5Ga3Al3 and CoGa3Al3. Correspondingly, the proportion of Co2+ ions decreased, likely due to the formation of Co3O4. No difference was found in the Ga 2p spectra of CoyGa3Al3 samples (Fig. 14A), the state of Ga3+ was not affected by the amount of Co incorporated. H2-TPR was applied for supplemental insights from the perspective of reducibility of Co species within the fresh catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 15. According to previous reports, the H2 consumption peaks below 600 °C should be attributed to the reduction of Co3+ ions of Co3O4 phase on the spinel surface, whereas the peaks above 600 °C corresponded to the reduction of cobalt ions in the lattice of Co-Al-O or Co-Ga-O spinel phase [43]. Additionally, the TCD signals were expected to keep changing beyond the temperature of 800 °C, indicating a strong interaction between Co and Ga (or Al) that prevented the complete reduction of cobalt ions to the metallic state. These results were in excellent agreement with most studies on Co-based catalysts, suggesting that lower Co content favors the formation of tetrahedral Co2+ sites that are active for ethane dehydrogenation, whereas Co3O4 crystallites are more likely to appear with higher Co content, which trigger the undesired cracking reaction. And also, the synergistic effect between gallium and cobalt is further demonstrated. On the one hand, the participation of cobalt optimizes the spinel structure of the catalysts that is conducive for the exposure of active Ga sites. On the other hand, gallium could effectively interact with cobalt ions, thus beneficial for the integration of cobalt into the expected active sites within the spinel lattice. 4 Conclusion A spinel-typed CoGa dual-atom catalyst has been developed for CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation. CoGa3Al3 was considered to be the optimal catalyst, with an initial ethane conversion of 47.7 % and ethylene yield of 40.6 %, which was much better than the single-atom counterparts CoAl6 and Co0Ga3Al3. In comparison with the direct dehydrogenation, the CO2-assisted reaction was found to be more advantageous over CoGa dual-atom catalysts, as the doped gallium greatly boosts the conversion of CO2 over CoAl6 as expected. And the participation of CO2 could not only facilitate the ethane conversion to ethylene by RWGS, but also enhance the stability of catalysts by reducing carbon deposits, as well as improve the selectivity by weaken the ethylene adsorption. A variety of characterizations offered insights into the gallium and cobalt species that were proposed to be active, suggesting that the majority of cobalt existed as tetrahedrally coordinated Co2+ ions, while gallium was predominantly in the form of Ga3+ ions distributed randomly among tetrahedral and octahedral sites. Ga species were believed to drive catalytic activity, considering their surface aggregation and higher exposure, and Al3+-O-Ga3+ sites should be further highlighted as possibly the most active. The dehydrogenation reaction was considered following a hetero-cracking mechanism, tightly relied on medium-strong acidity originating from tetrahedrally coordinated Co2+ and Ga3+ ions. And also, the base property of catalysts was non-negligible especially in the presence of CO2. In summary, this work provides fundamental implications for the rational design of dual-atom catalysts applied in CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation. And further exploration is needed on the mechanism of the synergistic effect between the two active components, in order to optimize the atom ratio and achieve better catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ga-doped spinel-typed Co-Al catalysts were prepared via one-step evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method. These catalysts present promising catalytic performance for CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation, which can be ascribed to the conjunction effect of cobalt and gallium species. The incorporation of Ga into the structure of Co-Al spinel has been recognized for enhancing CO2 conversion via reverse water-gas shift reaction, leading to a favorable equilibrium shift towards ethylene, along with an improved catalyst stability as a result of coexisting Boudouard reaction. Through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), NH3 and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) characterizations, coordinatively unsaturated Co2+ and Ga3+ cations were identified as collaborative catalytic active sites, with gallium species taking the prominent role. These sites were closely associated with the formation of acid-base pairs on the catalyst surface, which were crucial for the adsorption and activation of the reactants.
